title: Celebrations in Chai Nat
text:
NEWSPAPER SECTION: LIFE | WRITER: PICHAYA SVASTI - + To mark the start of Buddhist Lent on July 31, the people of Chai Nat will participate in the annual ceremony to present and wrap a huge saffron robe around the principal pagoda of Wat Phra Boromthat Worawihan in Muang district next Wednesday. 
The robe presentation ceremony at Wat Phra Boromthat Worawihan, Chai Nat. 
The procession of the robe by boat on the Chao Phraya River will start in front of the provincial governor's residence and end at the temple. The pagoda enshrines the Lord Buddha's relics and the temple boasts a 700-year-old well from which holy water comes out naturally. More importantly, water brought from the river in front of this temple is among water from several places all over Thailand used in royal ceremonies for officials to take the oath of allegiance. 
Also in Chai Nat, the annual boat racing will be held from next Wednesday to July 31 along a stretch of the Chao Phraya River near the provincial hall to Wat Phraya Tak. 
Races for boats with five oarsmen and 12 oarsmen will be held on July 22 and 23 on the river near the provincial hall and those for boats with 30, 40 and 55 oarsmen on July 30 in front of Wat Phraya Tak. The finals will take place in front of the provincial hall on July 31. The winning teams will receive the royal trophies of His Majesty King Bhumibol Adulyadej and Her Royal Highness Princess Maha Chakri Sirindhorn. 
There will be the Lent candle procession, a boat decoration contest, a beauty contest, concerts and a trade fair to sell One Tambon One Product (Otop) goods, farm produce and food. Call the Tourism Authority of Thailand's Suphan Buri Office on 035-525-867 or 035-525-880. Also call the provincial administration office on 056-411-234 for further details on the boat races. Lent candle festival 
The famous annual Buddhist Lent Candle Procession Festival is taking place and will last until the end of the month on Upparat Road in front of Wat Sri Ubon Rattanaram and on Rob Thung Sri Muang Road in Muang district, Ubon Ratchathani. 
On the same occasion, the International Candle Art Festival is being held with a display of contemporary beeswax art by artists from several countries, such as Nepal, Japan and Turkey, as well as leading art institutes in Thailand. Apart from the Thung Sri Muang public park which is beautifully decorated with beeswax art, visitors can visit Lent candle-making communities. They can also try making candles in the shapes and colours they like under the "B-I-Y" (Beewax It Yourself) activity. For more information, visit www.thaifest.com or contact the TAT Call Center 1672 or the TAT Ubon Ratchathani office on 045-243-770. Traditional arts exhibition 
From next Thursday until Aug 31 except on weekends and public holidays, the Office of Traditional Arts under the Fine Arts Department will host the "2nd Office of Traditional Arts Creates Arts of Siam Exhibition" at the Thai Arts and Craftsmanship Building on Phutthamonthon Sai 5 Road, Salaya, Nakhon Pathom. The objectives are to honour His Majesty King Bhumibol Adulyadej, Her Majesty Queen Sirikit and the entire royal family, as well as to showcase the office's art pieces and seek co-operation from people in preserving and carrying on Thai art. 
There will be demonstrations and workshops on creating traditional art, such as lacquerware, pearl inlay art on wooden key chains, miniature nang yai (shadow puppets), sculpturing traditional motifs and making khon masks, on July 23 and 24 from 9am to 4pm. Call the office on 02-482-1399.
